lines.text: Was I in here last night and did I spend a twenty dollar bill?
Yeah.
Oh boy, what a load that is off my mind! I thought I'd lost it.

My uncle, a balloon ascensionist, Effingham Hoofnagle, took a chance. He was three miles and a half up in the air. He jumped out of the basket of the balloon and took a chance of alighting on a load of hay.
Golly! Did he make it?
Uh... no. He didn't. Had he been a younger man, he probably would have made it. That's the point. Don't wait too long in life.
Lompoc is noted for it's beautiful girls. I imagine you've noticed them.
Yes. Yes I have. I'm a married man with a grown daughter - eighteen years of age.
Oh, I'd like to met her. I'm very fond of children. Girl children, around eighteen and twenty.

Ten cents a share. Telephone sold for five cents a share. How would you like something better for ten cents a share? If five gets ya ten, ten'll get ya twenty. A beautiful home in the country, upstairs and down. Beer flowing through the estate over your grandmother's paisley shawl.
Beer?

Beer! Fishing in the stream that runs under the aboreal dell. A man comes up from the bar, dumps $3,500 in your lap for every nickel invested. Says to you, "Sign here on the dotted line." And then disappears in the waving fields of alfalfa.

[about Souse]
He makes me sick!
Shall I bounce a rock off his head?
Respect your father, darling. What kind of a rock?
Oh... I knew this would happen! I was a perfect idiot to ever listen to you!
You listen to me, Og! There's nothing in this world that is perfect.
Mommy, doesn't that man have a funny nose?
You mustn't make fun of the gentleman, Clifford. You'd like to have a nose like that full of nickels, wouldn't you?
I'll starve myself to death, it's the easiest way out. It's not so difficult to do. I tried it yesterday afternoon.
Gosh!... Oh, pardon my language.
That's okay. I swear sometimes myself.
Don't be a luddy-duddy! Don't be a mooncalf! Don't be a jabbernowl! You're not those, are you?
I'll bet that's Og!
Mmm, he's got her bettin' now. She never gambled 'fore she met him.
What's the matter, Pop? Don't you love me?

[raising his hand in anger]
Certainly I love you!
Don't you dare strike that child!
She's not gonna tell ME I don't love her.
The jockey was a very insulting fellow. He referred to my proboscis as an adscititious excrescence. I had to tweak his nose.
Og Oggilby... sounds like a bubble in a bathtub!

[doing a crossword puzzle]
What's a six-letter word meaning "embezzlement"?
Prison.
Is that gun loaded?
Certainly not! But I think you are!
Can't we, eh, pull the shade?
You can pull anything you want in here. It's a regular joint.
Ever done any boondoggling?

[during the car chase]
The resale value of this car is going to be nil after this trip.

[to bank robber, after narrowly missing the police during a car chase]
Seems to be a great deal of traffic here for a country road. Don't you think?
Did you warble my little wren?
I want to prove to you that I'm honest, in the worst way.

[to Souse]
Say, you better come in and have a little poultice on the house.
Imagine a man who takes money out of a child's piggybank - puts in I.O.U.s!
I have a half interest in a cod liver oil mine down in Cape Cod. Snowed all winter. We did a lot of boondoggling. Did you ever boondoggle, Joe?

Boy, you're headin' right down my alley. In the old Sennett days, I used to direct Fatty Arbuckle, Charlie Chaplin, Buster Keaton, and the rest of 'em. Can't get the celluloid outta my blood. At nights I used to tend bar.
We're making motion picture history here.

[Demonstrating cigarette tricks]
I'll teach you when you grow up. I never smoked a cigarette until I was nine.
There was an article in there telling how I apprehended a couple of crooks. Who stole two million dollars - from Skinner's Lompoc Bank.

You would! Skinner's Lompoc Bank. Thems the shylocks that's got the mortgage on this house, ain't they? Haunting you from morning to night - the old pinch pennies! I'm sorry they didn't get away with the bag. Leave it to him. He would do a thing like that.

I've been in consultation with our Director and we've decided that what has been needed in this bank for a long time is a special officer. Or, to refer to the article of the underworld, a bank dick. In lieu of your heroism, your valiant, dauntless courage, I have the honor to offer you this position. The remuneration at first will be very small - we're a growing concern. We're young. But, there are a great many chances for advancement. Who knows? Within a short time, you may become my Vice President. My first and only vice.
Very good. What time in the morning?
The bank opens at ten o'clock.
Oh, well, that's all right. If I'm not here on time, just go right ahead without me. I'll catch up with ya.
I don't hang around that Black Pussy Cafe for nothin'.
I have a young daughter, marriageable age; also a small daughter; a nice wife and a mother-in-law that loves me like her own son.
Ah, the Black Pussy Cafe and Snackbar... How would you like to go in and have a little spot?
No, I never drink during the business hours. Thank you.
Just a little spot and we'll find out how Gumlake came out at Delmar today.
This-a, this place isn't crowded, is it?
No, if it wasn't for me the place would starve to death.
Well, I'll dawdled for about ten minutes.
Okay, we'll dawdle together.

This town has an altitude of 500 feet. Population is 4,500. Schools. Churches. Public Library. Three blocks of paved streets. Two trains a day - not counting the milk train that goes through at four o'clock in the morning. We have three drug stores - one actually sells medicine.
Stop. I'm dying. Could you direct me to a culvert.
Why don't you wait to get up to the hotel. Its only six blocks. We pass the Spanish-Americo Chili Parlor on the way up.
I shall make it my business to see that the Lompoc Ladies Auxiliary will be involved. I thought this was a family hotel?
Oh, yes. Yes, in deed, it is. Mr. Snoopington has a touch of ptomaine.
Hmm. It didn't smell like ptomaine.
Hello, Snoopy, old boy! How do you feel?
Oh, I feel as though I've been poisoned.
Hello, Doc. How are ya? How's business?
Oh, fair, fair. I don't suppose we'll ever get another whooping cough epidemic again.
Now, leave everything to me. I'll do the worry. Be happy! Gay! I'll have the management send you up a radio. Come on, Doc, we better be going. Toodle-oo.
We are grateful to you for retrieving the bank's funds.
Oh, well, that was in the line of duty.

And we feel we've shown our gratitude by giving you a position as bank's officer. But, when you caution Mrs. Muttle's little son, about carrying a toy pistol into the bank, that's going too far. I can not impress upon you to firmly, the Skinner Bank is a dignified institution.
Yeah, that's the way I always figured it, yes. I guess you figured it the same way, working here the same as I do.
Furthermore, I've been informed that you are a frequenter of a cafe known as the Black Pussy.
Would you like to examine the books at the Black Pussy - eh - Cafe?
Hi, Toots!
